title: Interpret Slope: Square Footage and Cost of Houses
question_text:
A local real estate agent is interested in the relationship between the cost of a house ($y$) in dollars and its area ($x$) in square feet. She randomly selects $50$ houses around town and computes the least squares regression line: $\hat { y } =136.89x+14578.91$.
Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the slope of the least squares regression line?

choices.text: For each dollar increase, the estimated square footage of the house increases by $136.89$.
For each dollar increase, the estimated square footage of the house increases by $14578.91$.
For each additional square foot, the estimated cost of the house increases by $\$136.89$.
For each additional square foot, the estimated cost of the house increases by $\$14578.91$.
Since we are not given the $50$ data points, it is impossible to interpret the slope of the least squares regression line in this problem.

solution:
This question addresses the issue of being able to find the slope and interpret it. The slope is the number in front of the $x$-variable, which in this case is $136.89$.

Therefore, we can eliminate Choices 'B' and 'D' since they suggest slopes of $\$14578.91$, which are found by taking the $y$-intercept of the least squares regression line. Again, we are looking for the slope.

We can also eliminate Choice 'E', as we are given the equation of the line and therefore do not need the $50$ data points.

Slope is:

$$\frac { \text{rise} }{ \text{run} } =\frac { y }{ x }$$

...which in this case is: $ \dfrac { \text{cost} }{ \text{square footage} }$

Since 136.89 is the same as

, then for each additional square foot, the estimated cost of the house will increase by $136.89.
